The President of the United States of America takes pleasure in presenting the silver star to second lieutenant Charles Robert Eisenbach, United States Marine Corps.

For conspicuous gallantry and intrapetity in action while serving as platoon commander with company D first reconnaissance battalion, first marine division, FMF in connection with operations against the enemy in the Republic of Vietnam.
On 4 July 1968, second lieutenant Eisenbach was leading a reconnaissance patrol.
When the unit suddenly came under intense small arms and automatic weapons fire from a numerically superior North Vietnamese Army Force and the lead elements were pinned down.

Realizing the seriousness of the situation, he immediately directed the remainder of his men to maneuver to aid the beleaguered Marines while he fearlessly moved forward to direct the fire of his men.
Ignoring the enemy fire impacting around him, he moved about the fire swept terrain deploying his men into advantageous firing positions and directing their fire until he was seriously wounded.
Although he was partially paralyzed and unable to move, he continued to direct his men while simultaneously adjusting airstrikes and supporting artillery fire upon the hostile positions.
Disregarding his painful injury, he resolutely controlled his unit throughout the remainder of the firefight.
His heroic and timely actions were an inspiration to all who observed him and contributed significantly to the accomplishment of his unit's mission.

By his courage, superb leadership and unwavering devotion to duty in the face of great personal danger, second lieutenant Eisenbach upheld the highest traditions of the Marine Corps and of the United States Naval Service.

My class, we were kind of put out because our anchor man was a foreign national, I think, from a country that didn't even have a Navy.
So, we were like, do we even want to fork over this buck for this guy?
And of course, we did because that was just, that's a tradition. It's always been that way.
So, you show up at TBS, and now it's 1968.
No, no. I graduated in June of, June 7th of 67.
And I put in for the first basic school class that was forming, which is first of July.
That was the beginning of the fiscal year back then, July 1st.
So, you know, I had a few weeks at home, boom, right back down to Quantico, to start the basic school.
Okay, so you started in the summer, sometime in the summer, 67.
Right. And how well did the Naval Academy prepare you for the basic school?
I think pretty well. Of course, we didn't ever get into the tactical side of things at the Naval Academy for the Marine Corps.
But, you know, you were in good shape. You obviously could wear your uniform, whichever it was in Marine Corps or Navy uniform.
Well, because you've been doing it for the past four years.
And I had gone to jump school between, on my summer leave, between junior and senior year.
And, you know, the physical requirements for that were pretty demanding.
You know, we got down to Fort Benning in August after crews.
And, man, that baby is hot, that red clay in Georgia reflects that heat up. And you sweat.
I saw those midshipmen coming.
And of course, you know, we were, we'd be running around with Navy cheers and any cadre, you know, staff sergeants that could pop up and, you know, halt us and drop us for pushups and everything.
Which we loved.
I don't think there were any UDT or SEAL groups going through when we went through, but they just ate the program up, you know.
Needless to say.
Yeah, I went, I was one of the, eventually SEAL stopped going to Airborne School at Fort Benning, Georgia and started running it in-house.
Okay.
But yeah, I was lucky enough to go to Airborne School. And, yes, the instructors down there definitely appreciated our presence in the last know-how.
Surely they did.
It's ridiculous, too, because we're coming out of, you know, buds literally a week, whatever, you know, we travel across country, we show up there.
So we're in really good shape.
So there was really nothing that they could do to us that would hurt us.
And we just would, and of course that encouraged guys to be, you know, wise asses.
And, you know, you know, I'm going to make you do pushups. You can't make me do enough pushups. So there's that whole thing going.
And now that you're at TBS though, well now you know exactly what's going to happen. You know you're going to go to Vietnam.
Right. Regardless of your MLS that you came out with, of course I'm going to be an O3 and most of my friends did too.
Oh yeah, that's a good point. So it's not actually guaranteed. So I'm thinking you still have to do a service selection inside or whatever, a job selection inside the Marine Corps.
Exactly, exactly. You put in for your top three and you hope you get number one, a Carson.
And the most guys did, you're pretty savvy about your capabilities and your, you know, likes and dislikes by the time you get to TBS, I think regardless of where you come from.
You know, we had a lot of recent ROTC grads and recent OCS grads and enabled kind of grads. And you couldn't distinguish who came from what pipeline.
You know, they're all pretty motivated folks back then. And I'm sure all the instructors must have been guys that were coming off of tours.
They were just back from their tours. I mean, they were all captains or above. Yeah, very sharp guys. They didn't pick slackers to be instructors at TBS.
And how, I mean, compared to the Naval Academy, was it just a totally different vibe of seriousness because they know what exactly what they're preparing you guys for?

It sure was. You know, you're here on problems, daytime problems, nighttime problems, didn't matter when they ended. And if you got back and turned in any gear you checked out at 3 a.m. in the morning, you're still up, you know, at 030 the next morning.
You didn't do that at the Naval Academy. You know, you had study hour and stuff like that. But now there was a definitely heightened level of seriousness at the basic school.
Again, all the instructors who were giving you straight poop, you know, because they had just come back from there or recently back my platoon commander. We had platoon of about 50 guys.
He was a captain, two silver stars, well decorated. Big guy. You know, they don't take again.
Rincorrel, etc. All kinds of ways. They look at how you did at basic school, your height versus your weight.
Some other, obviously other factors before they assign you someplace like if you're, if you think you want to get to 8th and I,
and be part of that in Washington, DC, you know, you've got to be like six feet or higher and taller or whatever.
Because, you know, they're standing on the cream of their crap because you're representing the, you know, I say somewhere in front of the public on a regular basis.
And rightfully so, you know, all the services do that. You know, the guards at Arlington aren't, you know, four feet eight and sloppy.
You know, they're all standing tall and looking good and very professional. Needless to say.
How hard was it to, you know, when you, when you started picking your job, obviously you said you wanted to be an infantry, infantry platoon commander.
How much competition was there for that? Did you have guys that were like, oh, I'm not doing that.
I'm not doing that job. You can have it. What's there, what's their competition for it?
I think there was only competition. We didn't feel competition, you know. Obviously had to do well on the O course and all the different evolutions.
You had to pass the PRT and, you know, you had to do well in land navigation, daytime, nighttime.
Do well on the rifle range and pistol range. But that was, that was just part of the competition of TBS. You were always competing with your, with your, what do you call?
Your classmates, yeah, your classmates at TBS.
But, you know, a lot of guys wanted to go infantry and obviously not everybody was going to go infantry.

I don't know what the selection process was, but I had a good friend from the Naval Academy. Not really a good friend, but he, he was, he was one kind of guy that would go around and say, are you going to go infantry two?
Also, meaning also, and of course, you had no idea. It depends on what the Marine Corps.
So, what the selection process was and whether you made or not and ended up not getting infantry, which was probably, probably a good move for him and the Corps.
Is there any, is there anything that you had struggles with when you're going through the basis hole?
Other than maybe, you know, the O-Course or something like that, but that was just like, you know, a eight minute struggle.
And as long as you were doing the best, the best you could, you know, they didn't beat you up too hard or mark you down.
But no, I didn't really feel that there was anything that was going to hold me back.
And they're training you with all the tactics, small unit tactics, naval gunfire, calling for fire.
Are you feeling like, were you feeling like you were getting good preparation for the battlefield?
I did. What the, what the basis school does is teach you everything you need to know as a company level officer, you know, from your time as a second lieutenant up to, to a captain.
After that, there's another school. There's, I'm not sure what it's called, but, you know, for senior captains and new majors.
But, you know, I felt well prepared. They had a Vietnam village built up in Quantico, staffed, of course, by Vietnamese.

And, you know, you practice that, you know, you did helicopter operations, you did walking insertions, you did land navigation daytime and night, which I'm sure you know, it's a different horse of a different color.
It is indeed.
But apparently it was pretty proficient. I graduated seventh in the class, not first like a web did in his class, but that's okay.
Seven was good enough for a letter of accommodation coming out of the basic school.
And that's seven out of class, how many?
About 240 years.
Okay. So, it seems like you were better at the field craft than you were at the academic school.
Well, this is true. In fact, in fact, you know, I got shot in the head and I have classmates who said, who still say to this day, we think that made you smarter.
Because I did go on to graduate school and get a master's in a PhD, you know, after I was retired out of the Marine Corps.
And maybe there's something to that, I don't know.
So then, so the basic school is what, six months long?
About five and a half then, you know, they were shortening it up.
Five and a half months long, you get done with the basic school, you get infantry.
Right.
And then what happens?
I got selected for reconnaissance replacement training, which was a couple of weeks in Southern California, a week at Penelton.
Again, from more supporting arms training in artillery, that sort of thing, air.
And then a week at Carnado for learning about naval gunfire support.
Did you use the board, what is it called, the smoke board?
Did they have the little fake terrain setup that you could call for fire on?
I went to the Marine Corps naval gunfire school and they had this terrain board.
And it was kind of like a, it must have been built in like 1975.
And when you'd call for fire, if you got in the right spot, little smoke would come up through that spot.
And it was like you were looking at, you know, through binoculars somewhere.
It was pretty good.
No, never saw anything like that.
I believe we were actually firing real-life artillery at Penelton.
And at the naval gunfire support school, we had this big board, but it was blue.
It was ships in the ocean per se.
But that was interesting because I did one night get to fire the cruiser providence in Vietnam, which was fun.
They couldn't use their six inch guns because they're too flat.
So they used their five inch, you know, bringing in direct fire on.
We had a bunch of lights below us.
I think folks were trying to move their troops around in the middle of the night.
And this was on call for us, so we used it.
So you got to use the naval gunfire?
I did.
That was like a dream of mine.
Never since I sat there on that little terrain board.
It was a dream of ours.
And I got to use my Bravo Zulu term at the end of it.
I like them for their fire.
The real Bravo Zulu.
The real Bravo Zulu.
That is outstanding.
That is outstanding.
I never even got close to even remotely thinking about calling for a new gunfire for real.
So I probably went too close to big waterways.
Yeah.
I don't know.
There's always that thing where guys want to fire a bunch of different weapons.
In combat, right?
And I had one guy get shot in the chest, but it hit him in the chest plate.
So I wasn't with him, but they actually had video of that.
So you get shot in the chest plate.
And so he's all mad.
He's mad and he shoots a bunch of machine gun rounds.
And someone goes, hey, shoot your pistol out of two.
And he goes, he looks at him and he's like, why?
And he says, we'll make you feel better.
So he pulls his pistol out and shoots that too.
And I'm sure if he would have had naval gunfire, who knows?
Maybe he would have gone for it.
I don't know about the pistol.

When we fired the 45 or qualification down at TBS, I think our instructor actually told us, you know, in combat, if this is all you've got, you're probably just better off throwing the pistol at him and shooting at him because he had a better chance of hitting him.
The bad guy on the other end.
Did you guys not have infantry officer course back then?
Because that's like a multi-month course now after TBS.
We did not.
You were considered good to go after graduation on TBS.
Now they have a 10 week officer or infantry officer training course, which I think would have been outstanding, but we had what we had.
So you go to this recon course.
And so now, are you getting jump paying all that stuff now?
No, you know, even when I was jump qualified, if you're not in a unit that maintains your jump qualification in the core, you don't get jump paid.
In fact, we got to Vietnam in first recon battalion.
There was only one company that maintained their jump status that was Charlie Company and they were the force recon company.
They did the same thing as the battalion recon companies did, but they did maintain their jump status.
So they got jump paying ever.
XR-75 bucks a month, which is a big deal back then.
So you end up going through this recon training and then what happens?
And it's time to deploy to Vietnam.
It's time to get on a bus and head up to Air Force Base in San Bernardino.
Don't know the name of it, but yeah, flew to Okinawa.
Spend a week there for the kind of triple to in.
Are you with all different branches of servicemen or are you just with Marines at this point?
Going over flew on Saturn, Airlines, I believe.
You know, a non-sked, non-sked airline to Okinawa.
Oh, just like civilian was there.
Civilian, what do they call hostesses?
Stuartuses all night?
Oh yeah, yeah, yeah.
A few stews.
By the tenants.
By the tenants.
But typically you wouldn't have anything to do in Okinawa.
All you've waited for your assignment to be flown into country.
When we got to Okinawa, there was about five of us that were traveling together.
We had been at the recon replacement training together.
And we were just milling around the receiving area after we got off the plane.
And somehow I got up above somehow, higher up than the crowd below me.
And I'm watching.
And there's this young Lance Corporal with a clipboard.
He's going to each of the second tenants that I had, you know, my buddies and asked him some question.
And they're going, oh no.
So I said, I said, this poor kid, I've been in this position before.
I'll find out what's going on.
So he, he, but he needed his, his company gun or something had sent him down.
He needed a signature from an officer to run three plane loads of Marines through a little program on an Okinawa where you fan fire the M16.
Because none of us had ever seen an M16, much less fired one before we went in if we had none.
And so you had fan fire, familiarize, familiarize yourself fire.
The M16 before you went in country made sure all your shots were up to date and all your paperwork was up to date.
So I said, sure, you know, so I signed for him.
I'd have to get up every night, every other night while I was there for about a week, meet incoming plane at about 2 a.m. in the morning.

Find the senior, listen guy on the plane, form these guys up, take him over to a barracks, have him draw mattress, you know, flop down, tell him to beat, you know, had to be out next morning at 7th or the morning and go to the chow.
And then we start him through the little program that you had to go through before you could get in country.
So I met my three planes in a little more than a week's time.
I was desperately afraid my, my officer buddies were going to rotate into country before I did.
Didn't happen, we all went off together. But anyway, it's an interesting week.
Would you shoot in the basic school, the M14?
M14, you know. How'd you feel about the M16 when you got it?
I loved it. Lightweight, almost lightweight.
Unfortunately, most Marines, and we found out that they had pitted barrels.
And sure enough, I had a trade mind, you know, what the two after I got there.
One that was a newer one with a good barrel.
That's crazy, you guys didn't even get, you didn't even shoot that weapon until you got the Okinawa.
That's right.
And then was the other training course that are giving you like basic preparation for Vietnam, jungle navigation or something like that?
In Okinawa?
Yeah, you were just kind of on your own until you rotated in.
K-SUN was getting hot then.
So we used to go to some three-shack operations shack of some outfit on Okinawan.
And hear the morning brief about K-SUN and kind of look at each other and say,
do you want to get sent there? No.
No, no, no.
So then you spend that, so you spend that one as a week in Okinawa?
Yeah, but now you guys all fly over to Vietnam.
Right. And where do you find him?
And then when you get there, what's that process like?
That process, we get there in the evening, it's dark, again, somebody met you.
Yeah.
Took you off somewhere, you grabbed a mattress, flopped you down on some barracks at the end of the runway.
And you slept until the next morning with all this effort taken off above you.
No sleep.
Did you have that stereotypical moment that people talk about, which is the guys that are going home,
the guys that are rotating home after their year, and you see that contrast between the new guys showing up with their brand new gear,
and the old guys that are heading home and they look like they've been through hell and bad?
Never saw anybody that was going home down at the Nang Airfield.
Didn't seem we arrived sometime in the middle of the night and was dark, and we had no...
You have that little kind of internal feeling of impending doom or dread or something.
I don't know what it was. Maybe it was just your adrenaline pumping, that you're finally going to get in country.
What's going to take incoming rounds while you're landing? No, it's a normal landing.
You get off the aircraft, somebody meets you after this way, listen guys that way.
Drew, you're a mattress straight asleep with the rest of the night.
Do you know where you're heading at this point?
You knew the division you were going to.
The first or third, third was up north in North I-Core, first was down around the Nang area.
I was going to the first division. You didn't even know if you were going to get to the recon battalion.
You went to division, the next day we went to division, we got to introduce the commanding general for some reason.
We were required to sit down, gave us a big book, Rules of Engagement, you had to read that, sign that you'd read it and understood it.
Then you got sent off to your unit.
Three of us were lucky enough to go to the reconnaissance battalion. The other two, they went off to regular grant units, infantry units.
So when you get your assigned to recon, and then what do you do? You guys drive up there, you take a helicopter up there, how you get up to your actual unit.
The actual unit, first recon battalion was located just below and across the street from the division headquarters.
So you walked down there.
As I said before, we had the one company, Charlie Company, that wasn't with the battalion in Nang, it was forward based at Fou-Bai.

They're the ones that kept up the jump status. One of my buds, who had gone through the recon replacement training, I was slated to go up there because I was single up to their force reconnaissance company.
He asked if I would mind giving that position to him if it was okay with the colonel because he was married and expecting their first kid to need that extra 75 bucks.
I was just happy to be there. I said, sure, take it if that's what you want, that's no big deal.
So he went up to the force company in Fou-Bai, I stayed there with the battalion in Nang.

And then what was checking in like, I mean, you're showing up there, you're a new guy, these guys have been in country, and this is something that always surprised me about Vietnam, is that you guys would rotate,
just one individual placements, whereas for me, all my deployments were, the whole unit is going in and the whole unit is leaving.
And so that's got to be a weird thing showing up as a new guy, and there's a bunch of people that have been there for, I guess, between two days and 360 whatever days.

Right, you are. I mean, my working premise when I got to Vietnam was that anybody who was there a day longer than I would, than I'd been there, was a day smarter about the situation or a day more experience than by God, I was going to listen to this person, you know.
But interesting enough, my platoon wasn't even there. They were a board ship with the afloat of battalion.
And we, Rincar always kept a battalion float off the coast of Vietnam that could jump in to an operation, you know, at a moment's notice, give or take.
And they always had a reconnaissance platoon with them, and they apparently used them pretty much as point for the battalion. So that was not a plumb job.
But my platoon with its outgoing platoon commander was a board ship, so I didn't see them for two weeks.
I just, I had nothing to do except I got tasked to sit on court marshals.
You know, I had unit grades, quarterly grades or something like that would or do.
I had to go, oh my guys, service record books and give them a grade for their performance over the last quarter without knowing them, without having seen them.
And this was going to be used for promotions. So I did the best I could, you know, I took a, in service record book, how long the guy had been the court in country, had been wounded.
What was the level of education, you know, I signed a few points and then, you know, like one to ten.
And then I added everybody's points up and I had a grade to give them and recommended the top three for promotion or something like that.
It was crazy, but I had to do it.
You know, to hear what you did.
We were just complimenting the brilliance of the Marine Corps. I mean, you got to tell a story like that.
Okay, so then did you eventually get flown out to the ship to be with them or did they come back?
No, they came back. They rotated back. They rotated back. They were just filthy dirty. I think they came right from the bush.
And the tenant, I got to talk to you for about ten minutes because he was like overdue to rotate out of country.
So he just, he just wanted to get a shower, get on a uniform, get back down to the nag and fly out.
What pearls of wisdom that he give you in those ten minutes?
He, he told me who the, who the best guys in the platoon were and who I think he thought I might want to keep my eye on. And that was about it.
No, no tactical advice on anything.
What's interesting, you know, I always say that leadership is the most important thing.
And what he was trying to give you is a heads up on who is like who is the best guys and from a leadership perspective.
That's interesting.
He just wanted out.
I didn't just want to get out.
But I wasn't a hooch.
You know, with other lieutenants, second first lieutenants who have been there, you know, anywhere from maybe two months to four months.
And they were filling me in on, on, on how to operate, how to deal operating.
Was there anything that surprised you that you were hearing from those guys? Anything that, you know, you said, oh, I didn't really expect that?
Only thing that really surprised me, I think once, once I got into Recona and got working with him was that occasionally you had to go out far enough,
that you weren't under, or anybody's artillery fan.
You know, you weren't under, rarely were we under the 105 fan, and the 155 fan usually.
And then there was Army 175s, which were very scary things because the word was, they could click out a, they could, you know, bump out a click when they fire these things.
They were big. We flew over one time and I looked at them. I swear they drooped.
You know, 175 artillery paces. They were huge. I swear they drooped.
And then, of course, if you were out past the 175 fan, you had nothing but air to call on.
And that was about 20 minutes to get there.
And pilots never really trusted ground officers to, you know, to bring them in correctly.
So they'd always want to fly out an aerial observer, you know, one of these little spit-kid planes, you know, prowling them back.
And I don't know what they were. OV-10s, I think.
But that was kind of surprising because, but artillery over there was fantastic. Great.
You know, they, or on call 24-7, obviously.
The best thing I ever fired was Marine Corps self-propelled eight-inch. They were like a, look like a big tag with an eight-inch, you know, fired an eight-inch shell.
Boy, they were accurate to the nth degree, unbelievable.
But basically artillery was excellent over there. Say they're bacon many a time.
So when you, it's been two weeks, your guys get back, you take over the Splatoon commander.
What's your intro meeting with the guys in the platoon? What did you say to them?
Just kind of introduce myself. I probably told them the same thing I just told you. If you've been here one day along, and I have,
and you got a better idea, or think you do, talk to me. You know, I'm here to listen. You know, I want you all to get back home.
Obviously, you know, intact and not tacked in, as we used to say.
In fact, the five and a half months I was a platoon commander. We only took one serious casualty, and that was me.
And I wouldn't have it any other way. We were extremely lucky, but we were also pretty good, you know.
We didn't do dumb things. There were folks who would like harbor at night near a trail, and hope bad guys would come down it,
just so they could try to set up a hasty ambush. No, no, no. Once your troops knew that you were serious about their welfare, we would have done anything for you.
And of course, you'd do anything for them. I had 23 range of my platoon. Maybe a couple of corpsmen. They rotated in and out, according to the will of the Italian age station.
And the finest young men ever settled on assemble. I know most platoon commanders say the same thing, but these kids were average age, 19, average education, 9th grade.
You know, but they were taught, they were primal. If I had told them that we've been tasked to flap the Hanoi, drop in with a river raft and paddle up and free the folks out of the Hilton.
They would have been right there. They were just great kids. What was the, what was kind of normal? Well, first of all, what was your first operation they went on with these guys?
Well, first thing that I did was turn out to be a TET 1968 broke on my first snap in patrol. I was, they tried to get you on a snap in patrol or two before you started leading your guys.
So you know, you were just, you know, you're just there to observe and learn. And your patrol leader might be an E3. In my case, it was an E5, Sergeant E5. And we got up this ridge line.
And after crossing this path, it looked like the I5 of people pass and we got now, it was smooth. And we, we got up into a bad bunch of brush and some rocks. And we were looking up the ridge line.
And pretty soon, four, four NVA come, put them down, down this highway. So four. And then there was eight. And there was 16 32. We stopped counting.
And this is your first mission. This is the first. Yes, exactly. And is this your platoon? No, I was with somebody.
I'm just telling you, yeah. And the leader, the platoon leaders in E5. Well, yeah, the patrol leader was in E5.
The patrol leader was in E5. Great young man. Great young man. And so his, his rule of thumb was where there's four. There's more.
Because when we saw these four guys come out of the jungle down this ridge line, first thing was let's go set up an ambush. No, Sergeant said no, no, no, no, no.
Where there's four, there's more. We stopped counting at 400. And by now we had artillery coming in. We had air on the way.
We had an aerial observer up there. We fired artillery all day, all afternoon, into the night, into the evening.
We had puffed a magic dragon dropping flares with with jets coming in underneath it. We're dropping napom at night. Oh, it was unbelievable.
And this is your first time? Were you doing the call for fire? No, no, no, Sergeant was doing, yeah. I was, I was there to learn. And to the pucker factor was like this.
Guys would go on it, wanted to snap in patrols and never see anything. But and they might come to Vietnam. Yeah. And they maybe have little two laws of fear attitude.
But this was my welcome to be at now. And I thought it was great. I mean, we're dropping artillery on these guys. They're running down the path toward our position.
You know, and they're in the, they're in the brush. They're not on the path. But they're in the brush. We had brush. We had rocks on like our north side and our east side and west side.

West and north just had brush. And there's, you know, North Vietnamese, they're in the brush coming toward us. They're crying. They're screaming. You know, they're yelling from mom, whatever, whatever you do.

And if you're North Vietnamese soldier and they were going to, they were going to run right into us. So it started bringing our children behind us real close, you know, danger close. So we got shrapnel flying over our heads.
And of course, this, this dissuades these bad guys are coming toward us. Also, we had kids set up when they should have been only in flat like a moushiu pancake.

Take a piece of shrapnel right in his face and knocked out a few teeth and cut open his lip and everything. And the shrapnel was dropping down. I didn't burn right through your, through your utility shirt, burn your skin. You just, you just endured it.
It was, it was, it was a little hairy. So danger close rounds come in your first night out at Vietnam.
Oh, well, welcome to the world. And you guys, and you guys maintained your, your clandestine position. Oh, yeah. Oh, yeah.
How many guys were out there with you? Probably about 10, 11. That was a heavy patrol. Yeah. Wow. All right. So now at how many of those snapping patrols did you do?

Two. What was the next one? My second, the next one was, was even wasn't that interesting from a, a tactical point of view, but it was going to be led by a lieutenant who had got a little tanked up at the O club the night before.
Had given the patrol patrol order. So we're down there waiting for on the LZ wait for the insert helicopter to get ready to take us off.

Come down the hill was the battalion commander, Lieutenant Colonel. He, uh, comes over to our patrol points of the lieutenant. Pack, get back up, pack, group gear. You're going to the grunts, you know, boom. He was out.
Colonel system, he is Lance Carpoh system, I think you guys can run the patrol. Yes, sir. No problem. So we did. It was great.
But, you know, should can this guy is just right there on the spot. You could do that in, in recon. I had to do it once to one of my guys.

What the guy do that rated you firing him on the spot? Um, I had, my patrol was like cutting half. I let my platoon was cutting half. I let half of it, you know, anywhere from eight to 10 guys depending on who was not on R&R, who wasn't safe.
